title: ‘The Man Who Invented Motion Pictures’ Review: The Lost Prince of Film History
sub_head: He was the ﬁrst to make a motion-picture camera. Then he disappeared. A year later Thomas Edison came out with a strikingly similar machine.
body:
In Peter Bogdanovich’s “Nickelodeon” (1976), a comedy-drama about the early years of moviemaking, a novice actor played by Burt Reynolds finds himself in a bakery that fronts for an independent movie company—one that is running afoul of Thomas Edison’s film-camera patents. The scene ends with a patent enforcer gunning down a camera—“That man killed a box,” says Reynolds’s character—and a fight amid flour and baked goods. It’s all played for laughs, but it’s based on a kernel of truth: Moviemakers crossed Edison at their peril.
Audiences familiar with “Nickelodeon” might have a shock of recognition when reading Paul Fischer’s lively “The Man Who Invented Motion Pictures: A True Tale of Obsession, Murder, and the Movies,” in which Edison—and his patents—play a prominent role. As Mr. Fischer shows, any major technological advancement is likely to involve people who hog or deny credit, and the innovations behind filmmaking were no exception.
